repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fix handling of `activeParameter`: no longer defaults to 0 if missing or out of bounds.  
Current behavior violates the LSP spec; some servers may intentionally omit this value.  
For example, in languages with named arguments, `nil` means no parameter match.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -377,6 +377,10 @@ function M.signature_help(config)
     local total = #signatures
     local can_cycle = total > 1 and config.focusable ~= false
     local idx = active_signature - 1
+    local nresults = 0
+    for _ in pairs(results) do
+      nresults = nresults + 1

comment_data.body: The spec still says "if `activeParameter` is omitted or the value lies outside the range of `signatures[activeSignature].parameters`, it defaults to 0 if the active signature has parameters". I think that this PR removes that?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -817,17 +817,21 @@ function M.convert_signature_help_to_markdown_lines(signature_help, ft, triggers
     if type(doc) == 'string' then
       signature.documentation = { kind = 'plaintext', value = doc }
     end
+    -- Add delimiter if there is documentation to display
+    if signature.documentation.value ~= '' then
+      contents[#contents + 1] = '---'
+    end
     M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(signature.documentation, contents)
   end
   if signature.parameters and #signature.parameters > 0 then
     -- First check if the signature has an activeParameter. If it doesn't check if the response
-    -- had that property instead. Else just default to 0.
-    local active_parameter =
-      math.max(signature.activeParameter or signature_help.activeParameter or 0, 0)

comment_data.body:
With 3.17, it seems impossible to have no active arg because of this constraint that says treat both ommited `signatureHelp.activeParameter` and `signatureInfo.activeParameter` as resulting 0. 3.18 allows explicitly having no active argument, but this requires distinguishing between omitted fields and null values. However, with the current type `---@field activeParameter? uinteger|lsp.null` I don't see how this can be done easily. 

What if make `lsp.null` not just an alias for `nil`? Then, during body parsing, instead of `pcall(vim.json.decode, body, { luanil = { object = true } })` emit this `lsp.null` for nulls? I guess this would require some refactor of methods that may rely on `nil` representing `null`, but it would allow proper support for `?|null` fields. What do you think?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -817,17 +817,21 @@ function M.convert_signature_help_to_markdown_lines(signature_help, ft, triggers
     if type(doc) == 'string' then
       signature.documentation = { kind = 'plaintext', value = doc }
     end
+    -- Add delimiter if there is documentation to display

+    end
     M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(signature.documentation, contents)
   end
   if signature.parameters and #signature.parameters > 0 then
     -- First check if the signature has an activeParameter. If it doesn't check if the response
-    -- had that property instead. Else just default to 0.
-    local active_parameter =
-      math.max(signature.activeParameter or signature_help.activeParameter or 0, 0)

comment_data.body: Sounds reasonable, but then could we make that fix (in `vim.json.decode` I think?) before this LSP change? Until then I would move this PR to a draft and address the root issue.

comment_data.body: Or better put, if you're down for fixing https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31368 that would be very welcome indeed :)

comment_data.body:
It is so much easier for everyone if we just use the protocol name. Otherwise users have to piece together wth this means.
```suggestion
• |vim.lsp.buf.signature_help()| supports "noActiveParameterSupport".
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -222,6 +227,8 @@ LSP
   https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specification/#textDocument_linkedEditingRange
 • Support for related documents in pull diagnostics:
   https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-current/#relatedFullDocumentDiagnosticReport
+• |vim.lsp.buf.signature_help()| now supports displaying signature help
+  with no active parameter highlighted.

comment_data.body: True, gonna update the commit message as well
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -222,6 +227,8 @@ LSP
   https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specification/#textDocument_linkedEditingRange

+• |vim.lsp.buf.signature_help()| now supports displaying signature help
+  with no active parameter highlighted.

comment_regular_data.body:
> For example, in languages with named arguments, `nil` means no parameter match.

Servers should not be sending nvim signatures with nil active parameters though, as we don't set the respective `noActiveParameterSupport` capability that guards that: https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.18/specification/#signatureHelpClientCapabilities

We should though. @skewb1k could you please add that change to `make_client_capabilities`?

For now, since we can't distinguish null fields, `noActiveParameterSupport` capability is set to false.

Also, it seems more logical for `vim.lsp.util.convert_signature_help_to_markdown_lines()` to not accept the full `SignatureHelp` object. The `activeParameter` field doesn't make sense after merging responses from multiple clients into the signatures list. Though, to be fair, it doesn't fully make sense in the [LSP response itself](https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/2080) either.

> For now, since we can't distinguish null fields, `noActiveParameterSupport` capability is set to false.

Gotcha. And so it sounds like this is blocked by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31368.

> Also, it seems more logical for `vim.lsp.util.convert_signature_help_to_markdown_lines()` to not accept the full `SignatureHelp` object. The `activeParameter` field doesn't make sense after merging responses from multiple clients into the signatures list. Though, to be fair, it doesn't fully make sense in the [LSP response itself](https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/2080) either.

Fair. Not sure if that method is part of [our efforts of getting rid of `vim.lsp.util`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25272) anyway.

> Gotcha. And so it sounds like this is blocked by #31368.

It's not strictly blocked. This still fixes the appearance and one of the two edge cases (out-of-bounds value). The `noActiveParameterSupport` part can be handled after omitted fields support lands, possibly in a separate issue. But I'm not insisting on that.

> Fair. Not sure if that method is part of [our efforts of getting rid of `vim.lsp.util`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25272) anyway.

It feels like it should be, since it adds another layer while being tightly coupled to the `vim.lsp.buf.signature_help` handler. I could try to factor it out - or adjust its params signature - I clearly see how it could be done better.

> It's not strictly blocked. This still fixes the appearance and one of the two edge cases (out-of-bounds value). The `noActiveParameterSupport` part can be handled after omitted fields support lands, possibly in a separate issue. But I'm not insisting on that.

In that case I'm happy to keep the appearance/out-of-bounds changes in this PR and then handle the `noActiveParameterSupport` in a later PR. But until then we are just not responsible for handling servers setting `activeParameter` to null.

After #34849 was merged and I revisited this, I regretted combining two unrelated changes in one PR. So I opened #35190 with just the display changes - hopefully, that will make review and history cleaner.
This PR will now target only activeParameter handling.
I'll update it in a few days when I have time.
@skewb1k Happy to approve this once this PR is rebased to exclude the changes from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35190 :)

Backport failed for `release-0.11`, because it was unable to cherry-pick the commit(s).

Please cherry-pick the changes locally and resolve any conflicts.
```bash
git fetch origin release-0.11
git worktree add -d .worktree/backport-34838-to-release-0.11 origin/release-0.11
cd .worktree/backport-34838-to-release-0.11
git switch --create backport-34838-to-release-0.11
git cherry-pick -x 7cc07e8383327f0701edccbe77120ceea2673bfa
```
